Both of you guys are lying because:
A) Product placement and paid advertisement are COMPLETELY different.
B) You're trying to throw EA under the bus for doing the exact same thing 
(something EA already got burned for) to try and make this seem more 
acceptable.

Product placement is when a company offers their product to be shown in a 
movie or a TV show for FREE for advertisement purposes.

Paid advertisement is when a company PAYS people to positively indorse 
their product to persuade people into buying it (the commercials you see on 
TV for example).

Microsoft and Machinima are both to blame for this. Stop trying to make it 
seem like this is normal business behavior because they both violated FTC 
rules and broke the law. When promoting a product and getting paid for it, 
that information has to be disclosed to the public or it's a federal 
offense. That's why people are angry, not because Machinima became sell 
outs.﻿

may not disclose the terms or payment of the endorsement".

+MrCodeman93 Well there's your first problem - giving even a single shit 
about things that "major" nelson says, the LITERAL poster boy for Xbox. And 
depending on when he tweeted it (which tweeting is super credible on it's 
own accord) he may have legitimately been under the impression that it was 
going to be exclusive, and things could have changed or he might have been 
misinformed.

But regardless of that, 720p looks just fine when it's rendering natively 
as such through a GPU. Videos that render in 720p (vs 1080p) are going to 
look lower quality because they are pre-rendered at a lower pixel ratio. It 
does not factor the interlacing which 1080i televisions or the fact that a 
GPU can render at 720p, with a much higher resolution, or PPI. With 1080i 
if your image moves quickly you will get a ghost effect due to the way 
interlacing works (half of the image is loaded every 30th of a second). 
That may not seem like much but it's highly noticeable in fast paced action 
and racing games. As well, the majority of high definition television shows 
only come through in 720p and so the majority of 1080i sets have to upscale 
the image regardless. 

HOWEVER, even without factoring in your television set's display, by 
rendering at 720p you lower the resolution which allows for more objects to 
be generated on screen without suffering from any kind of lag due to 
overwork of the GPU trying to upscale. As a PC gamer I struggle with this 
often with trying to find a balance between performance and resolution 
(though there are MANY more factors on PC which can affect performance and 
so it is barely comparable). If I had a monitor that ran a native 
resolution of 1280x720 I wouldn't have an issue (which is roughly the 
output of the majority of affordable gaming laptops) however my native 
resolution is 1680x1080 and most games are not designed to operate highly 
in this environment without additional power in the form of RAM or high end 
GPUs. 

So in conclusion, the only people who are going to notice the difference 
between 720p and 1080i are people who have giant, 8 foot tall television 
sets. Though even in that case your television set would have to have built 
in buffers to distort the image to give it a softer image quality, since no 
movies or television shows are going to be rendered at a high enough 
quality to display accurately on such a screen without them. The entire 
"720pv1080i" argument is just uneducated folks who are caught up in the 
"HD" fad who don't understand all the different factors that come into play.

I've looked at the difference in resolution from both systems, and it's 
quite obvious that it's not system hardware creating these blurry and 
pixelated environments. It's caused by lazy developers not optimizing their 
graphics for each system. With AC:BF the foliage has quite clearly less 
Anti-Aliasing and all the bloom has been scaled back. With Call of Duty 
Ghosts it is clearly not even a resolution based issue, since a lot of the 
foliage has lower quality textures that aren't present in the PS4 version. 

I'm going to stop here so I don't continue tangenting, but I would like to 
hear your rebuttle.

Here is an educational comment for all the people damage controlling either 
Machinima or Microsoft. Here is an example of how advertising works, On 
Radio/Youtube (Even this show) they plug a product/company and say that 
"Todays show is brought to you by 'insert product' here". So it lets the 
viewer know that they have been paid to 'advertise' this product. Where as 
this contract stated that you must not say that you have been paid to 
promote this product. Here is exact wording from the FTC guidelines 
"Endorsements must be truthful and not misleading", from what i remember 
the contract was telling people to be untruthful and mislead the viewers 
into thinking that what they had to say about the Xbox One was their honest 
opinion. ﻿

I don't know why some people are having a hard time seeing what's wrong 
here. If someone reviews God Of War, Halo, or Metroid, for example, and for 
the whole review, they only tell you the positives about the game, and 
don't mention the negatives, like bad level design, short campaign, bad 
enemy A.I., etc... that's a problem. If they give the game a 8.5 or a 9.5, 
when it really deserved a 6.5, that's a problem. Normally we would think, 
either the person is a terrible reviewer, or they're kissing butt. But if 
they are being paid to review a game and, only say positive things about 
it, when the game has negatives that should definitely be mentioned in a 
review, that's a pretty big issue.
It doesn't matter that other companies are doing the same thing. It doesn't 
matter that "You don't care" or that it's be going on for ages. It's still 
wrong.

And this is more than just your basic product placement. Product Placement 
is usually pretty easy to spot. This is about not disclosing that they are 
being paid to review a product in a positive light. And only a positive 
light. That's the issue. We watch a video thinking/hoping it's an honest 
review, but we aren't being told that, for example, a review of Zelda is 
being sponsered by Nintendo Co. Or, a review for God Of War is being 
sponsered by SONY Corp. Or a review for Halo is being sponsered by 
Microsoft Corp. I'm sure if we knew that, we would take the review a lot 
differently. It's purposely misleading. Telling us a game is great when it 
isn't, and/or knowing you're telling us only the good things about the 
game. While purposely failing to mention any of the negatives. The issue is 
that the "Federal Trade Commission requires full disclosure of paid 
advertising in editorial content".﻿

Disconnect between people who have no idea how the system works from those 
in the system who don't understand what it is like for people outside the 
system is the problem here. Just about every publication has pointed this 
out yet people seem to still not understand how advertising works or what 
the actual problem was in this case.

To reiterate, the problem was that the contract Microsoft made with 
Machinima was poorly phrased regarding its disclosure. Youtube content 
networks such as Polaris or Machinima make these deals and usually relay 
the information to the individual content creators with all the legal 
requirements such deals come with. In this instance Machinima dropped the 
ball and did not include the standard disclosure requirement that all other 
deals normally have.

Things people don't seem to understand is that Microsoft was not just 
paying anyone to say nice things about the One. People had to sign up 
through Pop Tent, an online marketing platform, to qualify. Further there 
was a cap on the amount of money Microsoft would pay out for the content 
and all they requested for was 30 seconds of essentially ad-reel. It was 
actually a rather shitty deal if you were a content creator. $3 cpm is 
garbage but I suppose any little bit helps to some people.

People are so quick to instantly go to MAX CORRUPTZ when anything like this 
happens, partially because of the growing distrust in large publishers and 
platform holders due to legitimately poor business decisions, but its 
important not to go instantly into rage mode at the first sight of what 
might be a problem without reasoned, logical discussion.

I work in advertising, and used to work in publishing (for a very brief 
time). I also run a small blog. This really is very, very normal. Happens 
on broadsheets, too - they're called advertorials.

It's just too bad that this getting out there makes Machinima seem horrible 
for doing this, but every company, especially publishing whether video or 
written, does it. In some blogs I know, this is where a big chunk of their 
money comes from. The sponsored content is what really pays the bills. The 
money from ad placement paid via CPM or CPC is peanuts, really.

To kind of give some clarity to the reader/viewer, most bloggers or content 
producers clearly state either at the end or beginning of their piece if it 
is indeed paid content.

What sucks is their competitors (IGN, Gamespot, etc.) jumped on the story. 
And gamers being gamers, they will feel betrayed. To be honest, I kind of 
feel betrayed, too, despite knowing how the system works. In my eyes, 
Machinima reviews are to be trusted a little less, but that's what's good 
about the Internet. Somewhere out there, someone is offering their honest 
opinion and all you gotta do is look for them.﻿

console or not).

give a false impression that ordinary people and content creators are 
enjoying it more than they actually are. This is similar to astro-turfing, 
they are essentially buying positivity, the main problem, however, is that 
this isn't Microsoft delivered positivity. They are deliberately targeting 
seemingly honest, reliable sources of information (Youtubers, who are seen 
as gamers / people just like us) and trying to get them to sell the console 
to you, dishonestly, while leaning on their apparent honesty. They're 
advertising while pretending they're not, by co-opting the opinion, 
personality and reputation of others. 

The long and short of it is that they're trying to subtly manipulate the 
reception and uptake of their console, that much should be obvious by the 
fact that they are hiding the relationship they have with Machinima (not 
allowed to state the terms of the contract). As Total Biscuit said, why

promote it which is against the FTC Guidelines. When you pay for 
advertisement, the FTC guidelines state that "Endorsements must be truthful

when the contract stated that they must not say they have been paid.
